name: Birds Do It, Bees Do It Quiz | Miscellaneous Animal Trivia | 10 Questions

questions.text: These animals are hermaphroditic- both male and female at the same time. While mating, they shoot each other with 'love darts.'
questions.explanation:
Snails.

	It's thought that the 'love darts' may stimulate sperm production.

questions.text: In some species of this animal, the male lives only as a parasite upon the female.
questions.explanation:
Anglerfish.

	For many years, biologists thought that they were two different species and wondered why they found only female anglerfish...

questions.text: Males of these animals produce a secretion that literally glues the female shut after mating, hopefully keeping other males from fathering offspring.
questions.explanation:
Ground squirrels.

	This device is called a 'mating plug' and is said to resemble epoxy glue.

questions.text: The female of this animal has a walnut-sized body and a tongue almost three feet long. Larvae of this creature are born sexless, but if they smell the tongue of a female, they will turn into males, settle on the tongue, and become a parasite on the female.
questions.explanation:
Bonellia worm.

	Many species of worms, especially parasitic ones, have bizarre life histories.

questions.text: Males of these animals explode while mating (thus injecting a device into the female that permanently inseminates her) and die soon afterwards.
questions.explanation:
Honey bees.

	Perhaps the drone bee was the source of the saying, "go out with a bang"?

questions.text: Mating in these animals can last 56 hours.
questions.explanation:
March flies.

	In fact, almost the entire life span of the adult is spent mating.

questions.text: Males of this species build an elaborate structure of twigs and leaves to attract a mate, decorating it with shells, feathers and flowers (especially blue ones).
questions.explanation:
Bowerbird.

	There are several species of these Australian birds. The male dances in the bower to attract females.

questions.text: In one species of this animal, no males exist. Females produce young without males, the young being clones of themselves.
questions.explanation:
Whiptail lizards.

	This process, which is called 'parthenogenesis', is also found in many insects, such as aphids.

questions.text: If the male of a harem of these animals dies, the largest female in the harem becomes a male and takes over the job.
questions.explanation:
Cleaner wrasse fish.

	This is common in some families of fish.

questions.text: These animals gather in huge 'mating balls' composed of many animals. Usually, there is only one female in the center.
questions.explanation:
Garter snakes.

	The female thus finds the strongest and most agile male to mate with.
